Name: Abdomen, Acute
Description: A clinical syndrome with acute abdominal pain that is severe, localized, and rapid in onset. Acute abdomen may be caused by a variety of disorders, injuries, or diseases.

Name: Abdomen, Acute
Description: A clinical syndrome with acute abdominal pain that is severe, localized, and rapid in onset. Acute abdomen may be caused by a variety of disorders, injuries, or diseases.

Name: Abdominal Injuries
Description: General or unspecified injuries involving organs in the abdominal cavity.

Name: Abdominal Neoplasms
Description: New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.

Name: Abetalipoproteinemia
Description: An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.

Name: Abetalipoproteinemia
Description: An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.

Name: Abetalipoproteinemia
Description: An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.

Name: Abetalipoproteinemia
Description: An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.

Name: Congenital Abnormalities
Description: Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.

Name: Abnormalities, Drug-Induced
Description: Congenital abnormalities caused by medicinal substances or drugs of abuse given to or taken by the mother, or to which she is inadvertently exposed during the manufacture of such substances. The concept excludes abnormalities resulting from exposure to non-medicinal chemicals in the environment.

Name: Abnormalities, Multiple
Description: Congenital abnormalities that affect more than one organ or body structure.

Name: Abnormalities, Radiation-Induced
Description: Congenital changes in the morphology of organs produced by exposure to ionizing or non-ionizing radiation.

Name: Abnormalities, Radiation-Induced
Description: Congenital changes in the morphology of organs produced by exposure to ionizing or non-ionizing radiation.

Name: Abortion, Spontaneous
Description: Expulsion of the product of FERTILIZATION before completing the term of GESTATION and without deliberate interference.

Name: Abortion, Habitual
Description: Three or more consecutive spontaneous abortions.

Name: Abortion, Incomplete
Description: Premature loss of PREGNANCY in which not all the products of CONCEPTION have been expelled.

Name: Abortion, Missed
Description: The retention in the UTERUS of a dead FETUS two months or more after its DEATH.

Name: Abortion, Septic
Description: Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.

Name: Abortion, Septic
Description: Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.

Name: Abortion, Septic
Description: Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.

Name: Abortion, Threatened
Description: UTERINE BLEEDING from a GESTATION of less than 20 weeks without any CERVICAL DILATATION. It is characterized by vaginal bleeding, lower back discomfort, or midline pelvic cramping and a risk factor for MISCARRIAGE.

Name: Abortion, Veterinary
Description: Premature expulsion of the FETUS in animals.

Name: Abortion, Veterinary
Description: Premature expulsion of the FETUS in animals.

Name: Abruptio Placentae
Description: Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.

Name: Abruptio Placentae
Description: Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.

Name: Abscess
Description: Accumulation of purulent material in tissues, organs, or circumscribed spaces, usually associated with signs of infection.

Name: Abscess
Description: Accumulation of purulent material in tissues, organs, or circumscribed spaces, usually associated with signs of infection.

Name: Peritonsillar Abscess
Description: An accumulation of purulent material in the area between the PALATINE TONSIL and its capsule.

Name: Peritonsillar Abscess
Description: An accumulation of purulent material in the area between the PALATINE TONSIL and its capsule.

Name: Peritonsillar Abscess
Description: An accumulation of purulent material in the area between the PALATINE TONSIL and its capsule.

Name: Peritonsillar Abscess
Description: An accumulation of purulent material in the area between the PALATINE TONSIL and its capsule.

Name: Peritonsillar Abscess
Description: An accumulation of purulent material in the area between the PALATINE TONSIL and its capsule.

Name: Acantholysis
Description: Separation of the prickle cells of the stratum spinosum of the epidermis, resulting in atrophy of the prickle cell layer. It is seen in diseases such as pemphigus vulgaris (see PEMPHIGUS) and DARIER DISEASE.

Name: Acantholysis
Description: Separation of the prickle cells of the stratum spinosum of the epidermis, resulting in atrophy of the prickle cell layer. It is seen in diseases such as pemphigus vulgaris (see PEMPHIGUS) and DARIER DISEASE.

Name: Acanthosis Nigricans
Description: A circumscribed melanosis consisting of a brown-pigmented, velvety verrucosity or fine papillomatosis appearing in the axillae and other body folds. It occurs in association with endocrine disorders, underlying malignancy, administration of certain drugs, or as in inherited disorder.

Name: Severe Acute Malnutrition
Description: Acute form of MALNUTRITION which usually affects children, characterized by a very low weight for height (below -3z scores of the median World Health Organization standards), visible severe wasting, or occurrence of nutritional EDEMA.  It can be a direct or indirect cause of fatality in children suffering from DIARRHEA and PNEUMONIA. Do not confuse with starvation, a condition in which the body is not getting enough food, usually for extended periods of time.

Name: Shellfish Hypersensitivity
Description: Allergic reaction to SHELLFISH or shellfish products.

Name: Symptom Flare Up
Description: A transient exacerbation of symptoms of an existing disease or condition.

Name: Obesity, Metabolically Benign
Description: A sub-PHENOTYPE of obese individuals who have a risk for CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES between that of healthy individuals with normal weight and unhealthy individuals with obesity.

Name: Obesity, Metabolically Benign
Description: A sub-PHENOTYPE of obese individuals who have a risk for CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES between that of healthy individuals with normal weight and unhealthy individuals with obesity.

Name: Cold Injury
Description: A physical injury caused by exposure of the body to extremely low ambient temperatures that may lead to loss of body parts, or in extreme cases, death. Examples of cold injury are FROSTBITE and CHILBLAINS.

Name: War-Related Injuries
Description: WOUNDS and INJURIES and PSYCHOLOGICAL TRAUMA sustained during WAR.

Name: Late Onset Disorders
Description: Pathological conditions (Disorder, SYNDROME, or DISEASE) whose SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS manifest late in the life of an individual.

Name: Compassion Fatigue
Description: Emotional distress caused by repeated or prolonged expression of compassion or empathy. It may occur in individuals working in care giving professions.

Name: Fractures, Multiple
Description: Injuries involving the breaking of either several bones or one bone in two or more places.

Name: Fractures, Multiple
Description: Injuries involving the breaking of either several bones or one bone in two or more places.

Name: Drug Resistant Epilepsy
Description: Epileptic condition in which adequate trials of two tolerated and appropriately chosen and used ANTIEPILEPTIC DRUGS schedules to achieve sustained seizure freedom failed.

Name: Autoimmune Hypophysitis
Description: Immune-mediated inflammation of the PITUITARY GLAND often associated with other autoimmune diseases (e.g., HASHIMOTO DISEASE; GRAVES DISEASE; and ADDISON DISEASE).

Name: Autoimmune Hypophysitis
Description: Immune-mediated inflammation of the PITUITARY GLAND often associated with other autoimmune diseases (e.g., HASHIMOTO DISEASE; GRAVES DISEASE; and ADDISON DISEASE).

Name: Autoimmune Hypophysitis
Description: Immune-mediated inflammation of the PITUITARY GLAND often associated with other autoimmune diseases (e.g., HASHIMOTO DISEASE; GRAVES DISEASE; and ADDISON DISEASE).

Name: Canaliculitis
Description: Inflammation and infection of the lacrimal canaliculus area in the LACRIMAL APPARATUS.

Name: Incisional Hernia
Description: Protrusion of tissue at or near the site of an incision from a previous surgery.

Name: Incisional Hernia
Description: Protrusion of tissue at or near the site of an incision from a previous surgery.

Name: Plasmablastic Lymphoma
Description: Malignant lymphoma composed of large B lymphoid cells which have the immunophenotype of plasma cells and a predilection for the ORAL CAVITY.

Name: Plasmablastic Lymphoma
Description: Malignant lymphoma composed of large B lymphoid cells which have the immunophenotype of plasma cells and a predilection for the ORAL CAVITY.

Name: Plasmablastic Lymphoma
Description: Malignant lymphoma composed of large B lymphoid cells which have the immunophenotype of plasma cells and a predilection for the ORAL CAVITY.

Name: Mammary Analogue Secretory Carcinoma
Description: A malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells of the SALIVARY GLANDS, with microcystic architecture, low-grade nuclei, and granular vacuolated cytoplasm.

Name: Acne Conglobata
Description: Severe and chronic form of acne characterized by large, burrowing abscesses associated with disfigurement.

Name: Acne Conglobata
Description: Severe and chronic form of acne characterized by large, burrowing abscesses associated with disfigurement.

Name: Fused Kidney
Description: Congenital fusion of two kidneys.

Name: Fused Kidney
Description: Congenital fusion of two kidneys.

Name: Fused Kidney
Description: Congenital fusion of two kidneys.

Name: Fused Kidney
Description: Congenital fusion of two kidneys.

Name: Long Term Adverse Effects
Description: Persistent detrimental effects from treatment for a condition. Included are effects from surgery such as POSTOPERATIVE COMPLICATIONS, and from DRUG THERAPY, such as CHEMICALLY INDUCED DISORDERS, or other THERAPEUTICS. Failure to attain a desired outcome from treatment for the condition is not considered an adverse effect.

Name: Infectious Encephalitis
Description: Brain inflammation caused by an infectious agent.

Name: Infectious Encephalitis
Description: Brain inflammation caused by an infectious agent.

Name: Infectious Encephalitis
Description: Brain inflammation caused by an infectious agent.

Name: Infectious Encephalitis
Description: Brain inflammation caused by an infectious agent.

Name: Waterborne Diseases
Description: Illnesses due to micro-organisms and chemicals in drinking water, those caused by organisms having part of their lifecycle in water or those with water-related vectors, and others spread by aerosols containing pathogens.

Name: Unilateral Breast Neoplasms
Description: Tumors or cancer found specifically in one human BREAST, but not in both.

Name: Unilateral Breast Neoplasms
Description: Tumors or cancer found specifically in one human BREAST, but not in both.

Name: Degloving Injuries
Description: Avulsions of the superficial tissues of SKIN and SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE from the underlying FASCIA.

Name: Staghorn Calculi
Description: Renal calculi with a characteristic shape like antlers of a deer, formed as it extends into multiple calices of the RENAL PELVIS. A large number of staghorn calculi as well as other URINARY CALCULI are composed of STRUVITE.

Description: Renal calculi with a characteristic shape like antlers of a deer, formed as it extends into multiple calices of the RENAL PELVIS. A large number of staghorn calculi as well as other URINARY CALCULI are composed of STRUVITE.

Name: Talipes
Description: Deformity in which the foot is misaligned with respect to the TALUS in the ANKLE JOINT. While mostly congenital, as in CLUBFOOT, acquired deformities are included. Acquired talipedes are often associated with other foot deformities such as SYNDACTYLY and POLYDACTYLY.

Name: Talipes Cavus
Description: A foot deformity in which the arch of the foot is high and often the heel adducted.

Name: Metatarsal Valgus
Description: A foot anomaly in which the forefoot is angled outward relative to the hindfoot.

Name: Metatarsus Varus
Description: A foot anomaly in which the forefoot (METATARSUS) is angled inward relative to the heel.

Name: Anterior Cruciate Ligament Injuries
Description: Sprain or tear injuries to the ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT of the knee.

Name: Shoulder Injuries
Description: Injuries involving the SHOULDERS and SHOULDER JOINT.

Name: Tibial Meniscus Injuries
Description: Injuries to the TIBIAL MENISCUS of the leg.

Name: Coxa Magna
Description: Deformity of the hip characterized by enlargement and deformation of the FEMUR HEAD and FEMUR NECK, often with associated changes in the ACETABULUM. These changes may be secondary to other diseases (e.g.  LEGG-PERTHES DISEASE; ARTHRITIS; HIP DISLOCATION, CONGENITAL) or TRAUMA.

Name: Tarsal Coalition
Description: Congenital, complete or partial fusion of the TARSAL BONES of the foot. PES PLANUS is usually a feature.

Name: Tarsal Coalition
Description: Congenital, complete or partial fusion of the TARSAL BONES of the foot. PES PLANUS is usually a feature.

Description: Congenital, complete or partial fusion of the TARSAL BONES of the foot. PES PLANUS is usually a feature.

Name: Morton Neuroma
Description: A nerve inflammation in the foot caused by chronic compression of the plantar nerve between the METATARSAL BONES.

Name: Microtrauma, Physical
Description: Small injuries caused by external force applied to the body including bones, muscles, nerves and tendons.

Name: Brain Contusion
Description: A bruise of the brain from an impact of the skull.

Name: Brain Injuries, Diffuse
Description: Brain injuries occurring over a wide area instead of specific focal area.

Name: Brain Injuries, Diffuse
Description: Brain injuries occurring over a wide area instead of specific focal area.

Description: Brain injuries occurring over a wide area instead of specific focal area.

Name: Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy
Description: Degenerative brain disease linked to repetitive brain trauma. Progressive symptoms may include MEMORY LOSS; AGGRESSION; or DEPRESSION.

Name: Diastasis, Muscle
Description: Abnormal separation of muscles.

Description: Abnormal separation of muscles.

Name: Diastasis, Bone
Description: Abnormal separation of bones, often from a LIGAMENT.

Name: Diastasis, Bone
Description: Abnormal separation of bones, often from a LIGAMENT.

Name: Rotator Cuff Injuries
Description: Injuries to the ROTATOR CUFF of the shoulder joint.

Name: Rotator Cuff Injuries
Description: Injuries to the ROTATOR CUFF of the shoulder joint.

Name: Rotator Cuff Injuries
Description: Injuries to the ROTATOR CUFF of the shoulder joint.

Name: Elbow Tendinopathy
Description: Inflammation (tendinitis) or degeneration (tendinosis) of the tendons of the elbow.

Name: Elbow Tendinopathy
Description: Inflammation (tendinitis) or degeneration (tendinosis) of the tendons of the elbow.

Name: Brain Injuries, Traumatic
Description: A form of acquired brain injury which occurs when a sudden trauma causes damage to the brain.

Name: Brain Injuries, Traumatic
Description: A form of acquired brain injury which occurs when a sudden trauma causes damage to the brain.

Name: Brain Injuries, Traumatic
Description: A form of acquired brain injury which occurs when a sudden trauma causes damage to the brain.

Name: Rotator Cuff Tear Arthropathy
Description: Rapidly destructive shoulder joint and bone disease found mainly in elderly, and predominantly in women. It is characterized by SHOULDER PAIN; JOINT INSTABILITY; and the presence of crystalline CALCIUM PHOSPHATES in the SYNOVIAL FLUID. It is associated with ROTATOR CUFF INJURIES.

Name: Rotator Cuff Tear Arthropathy
Description: Rapidly destructive shoulder joint and bone disease found mainly in elderly, and predominantly in women. It is characterized by SHOULDER PAIN; JOINT INSTABILITY; and the presence of crystalline CALCIUM PHOSPHATES in the SYNOVIAL FLUID. It is associated with ROTATOR CUFF INJURIES.

Name: Crystal Arthropathies
Description: Joint disorders that are characterized by accumulation of microcrystals in and around the joint including in the SYNOVIAL FLUID. They are classified according to the chemical nature of the crystals such as CALCIUM PYROPHOSPHATE; basic CALCIUM PHOSPHATES; and monosodium urate (see URIC ACID).

Name: Enthesopathy
Description: A disorder occurring at the site of insertion of TENDONS or LIGAMENTS into bones or JOINT CAPSULES.

Name: Enthesopathy
Description: A disorder occurring at the site of insertion of TENDONS or LIGAMENTS into bones or JOINT CAPSULES.

Name: Giant Cell Tumor of Tendon Sheath
Description: A tumor arising in the SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE; SYNOVIAL BURSA; or TENDON sheath. It is characterized by OSTEOCLAST-like GIANT CELLS; FOAM CELLS; pigmented HEMOSIDERIN-laden MACROPHAGES and inflammatory infiltrate. It is classified either as diffuse or localized tenosynovitis.

Name: Giant Cell Tumor of Tendon Sheath
Description: A tumor arising in the SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE; SYNOVIAL BURSA; or TENDON sheath. It is characterized by OSTEOCLAST-like GIANT CELLS; FOAM CELLS; pigmented HEMOSIDERIN-laden MACROPHAGES and inflammatory infiltrate. It is classified either as diffuse or localized tenosynovitis.

Name: Giant Cell Tumor of Tendon Sheath
Description: A tumor arising in the SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE; SYNOVIAL BURSA; or TENDON sheath. It is characterized by OSTEOCLAST-like GIANT CELLS; FOAM CELLS; pigmented HEMOSIDERIN-laden MACROPHAGES and inflammatory infiltrate. It is classified either as diffuse or localized tenosynovitis.

Name: Bankart Lesions
Description: An anterior capsulolabral injury associated with a tear of the anteroinferior GLENOID LABRUM.

Name: Bankart Lesions
Description: An anterior capsulolabral injury associated with a tear of the anteroinferior GLENOID LABRUM.

Name: Hyperekplexia
Description: A neurological disorder characterized by an excessive startle reaction with ABNORMAL REFLEX;  MYOCLONIC JERKS; and MUSCLE HYPERTONIA.

Name: Anorectal Malformations
Description: Congenital defects in the anus and the rectum often involving the urinary and genital tracts.

Name: Anorectal Malformations
Description: Congenital defects in the anus and the rectum often involving the urinary and genital tracts.

Name: Tardive Dyskinesia
Description: Drug-related movement disorder characterized by uncontrollable movements in certain muscles. It is associated with a long-term exposure to certain neuroleptic medications (e.g., METOCLOPRAMIDE).

Name: Tardive Dyskinesia
Description: Drug-related movement disorder characterized by uncontrollable movements in certain muscles. It is associated with a long-term exposure to certain neuroleptic medications (e.g., METOCLOPRAMIDE).

Name: Tardive Dyskinesia
Description: Drug-related movement disorder characterized by uncontrollable movements in certain muscles. It is associated with a long-term exposure to certain neuroleptic medications (e.g., METOCLOPRAMIDE).

Name: Alert Fatigue, Health Personnel
Description: Mental fatigue experienced by health care providers who encounter numerous alerts and reminders from the use of CLINICAL DECISION SUPPORT SYSTEMS. As the numbers of alerts and reminders designed to provide meaningful assistance to the patient care process increases, many health personnel may ignore them.

Name: Pneumonia, Necrotizing
Description: Severe complication of pneumonia characterized by liquefaction of lung tissue.

Name: Pneumonia, Necrotizing
Description: Severe complication of pneumonia characterized by liquefaction of lung tissue.

Name: Pneumonia, Necrotizing
Description: Severe complication of pneumonia characterized by liquefaction of lung tissue.

Name: Multiple Chronic Conditions
Description: Two or more concurrent chronic physical, mental, or behavioral health problems in an individual.

Name: Familial Multiple Lipomatosis
Description: A rare autosomal disorder characterized by numerous encapsulated lipomas on the trunk and extremities. The lipomas are usually not painful but can cause pain when growing. In rare cases, one lipoma can become painful and progress to multiple painful lipomas; it is then referred to as Dercum's Disease Type III

Name: Familial Multiple Lipomatosis
Description: A rare autosomal disorder characterized by numerous encapsulated lipomas on the trunk and extremities. The lipomas are usually not painful but can cause pain when growing. In rare cases, one lipoma can become painful and progress to multiple painful lipomas; it is then referred to as Dercum's Disease Type III

Name: Familial Multiple Lipomatosis
Description: A rare autosomal disorder characterized by numerous encapsulated lipomas on the trunk and extremities. The lipomas are usually not painful but can cause pain when growing. In rare cases, one lipoma can become painful and progress to multiple painful lipomas; it is then referred to as Dercum's Disease Type III

Name: Microaneurysm
Description: Aneurysm of the MICROVASCULATURE. Charcot–Bouchard aneurysms are aneurysms of the brain vasculature which is a common cause of CEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE. Retinal microaneurysm is an early diagnostic sign of DIABETIC RETINOPATHY.

Name: Acute Febrile Encephalopathy
Description: Acute onset of fever accompanied by seizures, cerebral inflammation and a change in mental status (e.g., confusion, disorientation, and coma).

Name: Neonatal Sepsis
Description: Blood infection that occurs in an infant younger than 90 days old. Early-onset sepsis is seen in the first week of life and most often appears within 24 hours of birth. Late-onset occurs after 1 week and before 3 months of age.

Name: Neonatal Sepsis
Description: Blood infection that occurs in an infant younger than 90 days old. Early-onset sepsis is seen in the first week of life and most often appears within 24 hours of birth. Late-onset occurs after 1 week and before 3 months of age.

Name: Neonatal Sepsis
Description: Blood infection that occurs in an infant younger than 90 days old. Early-onset sepsis is seen in the first week of life and most often appears within 24 hours of birth. Late-onset occurs after 1 week and before 3 months of age.

Name: Small Fiber Neuropathy
Description: Disorder of the peripheral nerves that primarily impair small nerve fibers. The affected small nerve fibers include myelinated A-delta fibers (see A FIBERS) and unmyelinated C FIBERS. Because these small fibers innervate skin and help control autonomic function, their neuropathy presents with neuropathic pain, reduced thermal and pain sensitivity, and autonomic dysfunction (e.g. abnormal sweating or facial flushing). Small fiber neuropathy can be idiopathic or associated with underlying diseases (e.g., AMYLOIDOSIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; SARCOIDOSIS; or VASCULITIS).

Name: Stenosis, Pulmonary Vein
Description: Narrowing of the PULMONARY VEIN.

Name: Stenosis, Pulmonary Artery
Description: Narrowing of the PULMONARY ARTERIES.

Name: Zika Virus Infection
Description: A viral disease transmitted by the bite of AEDES mosquitoes infected with ZIKA VIRUS. Its mild DENGUE-like symptoms include fever, rash, headaches and ARTHRALGIA. The viral infection during pregnancy, in rare cases, is associated with congenital brain and ocular abnormalities, called Congenital Zika Syndrome, including MICROCEPHALY and may also lead to GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME.

Name: Zika Virus Infection
Description: A viral disease transmitted by the bite of AEDES mosquitoes infected with ZIKA VIRUS. Its mild DENGUE-like symptoms include fever, rash, headaches and ARTHRALGIA. The viral infection during pregnancy, in rare cases, is associated with congenital brain and ocular abnormalities, called Congenital Zika Syndrome, including MICROCEPHALY and may also lead to GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME.

Name: Emergence Delirium
Description: A form of DELIRIUM which occurs after GENERAL ANESTHESIA.

Name: Acute Retroviral Syndrome
Description: Early stage of HIV infection. Symptoms resemble INFLUENZA or INFECTIOUS MONONUCLEOSIS.

Name: Body Remains
Description: The physical entity of a deceased human or animal.

Name: Bunion
Description: Abnormal swelling of the inner aspect of the first metatarsal head affecting the first METATARSOPHALANGEAL JOINT.

Name: Fibromatosis, Plantar
Description: A fibromatosis of the plantar fascia characterized by thickening of the fibrous bands on the plantar aponeurosis in the sole of the foot and toes.

Name: Fibromatosis, Plantar
Description: A fibromatosis of the plantar fascia characterized by thickening of the fibrous bands on the plantar aponeurosis in the sole of the foot and toes.

Name: Fibromatosis, Plantar
Description: A fibromatosis of the plantar fascia characterized by thickening of the fibrous bands on the plantar aponeurosis in the sole of the foot and toes.

Description: A fibromatosis of the plantar fascia characterized by thickening of the fibrous bands on the plantar aponeurosis in the sole of the foot and toes.

Name: Fibromatosis, Plantar
Description: A fibromatosis of the plantar fascia characterized by thickening of the fibrous bands on the plantar aponeurosis in the sole of the foot and toes.

Name: Fractures, Avulsion
Description: Tearing away of the CORTICAL BONE fragment at the location of a strong ligament or tendon attachment. The bone fragment detachment site often occurs near a soft site (e.g., GROWTH PLATE) at the base where LIGAMENTS; TENDONS; or JOINT CAPSULES attach. In younger patients it is most often caused by a sudden forceful pull on a tendon in the opposite direction of the bone movement. In the elderly it is associated with osteoporotic INSUFFICIENCY FRACTURES.

Name: Crush Injuries
Description: Excessive compression of parts of the body that causes muscle swelling, fracture, and/or neurological disturbances in the affected areas. Crush injury with systemic manifestations is referred to as CRUSH SYNDROME.

Name: Cellulite
Description: Skin lumpiness or skin surface dimpling often seen on the thighs, buttocks and abdomen. It is due to protrusion of SUBCUTANEOUS FAT into the DERMIS layer of skin.

Name: Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults
Description: Autoimmune diabetes in adults with slowly progressive PANCREATIC BETA CELL failure and the presence of circulating autoantibodies to PANCREATIC ISLETS cell antigens.

Name: Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults
Description: Autoimmune diabetes in adults with slowly progressive PANCREATIC BETA CELL failure and the presence of circulating autoantibodies to PANCREATIC ISLETS cell antigens.

Name: Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults
Description: Autoimmune diabetes in adults with slowly progressive PANCREATIC BETA CELL failure and the presence of circulating autoantibodies to PANCREATIC ISLETS cell antigens.

Name: Bilateral Vestibulopathy
Description: Impairment of the vestibular function of both inner ears which can cause difficulties with balance, gait, VERTIGO, and visual blurring.

Name: Bilateral Vestibulopathy
Description: Impairment of the vestibular function of both inner ears which can cause difficulties with balance, gait, VERTIGO, and visual blurring.

Name: Bilateral Vestibulopathy
Description: Impairment of the vestibular function of both inner ears which can cause difficulties with balance, gait, VERTIGO, and visual blurring.

Name: Cone-Rod Dystrophies
Description: Genetically heterogeneous and sometimes syndromic (e.g., BARDET BIEDL SYNDROME; and SPINOCEREBELLAR ATAXIA TYPE 7) retinopathies with initial RETINAL CONE involvement. They are characterized by decreased VISUAL ACUITY; COLOR VISION DEFECTS; progressive loss of peripheral vision and night blindness.

Name: Cone-Rod Dystrophies
Description: Genetically heterogeneous and sometimes syndromic (e.g., BARDET BIEDL SYNDROME; and SPINOCEREBELLAR ATAXIA TYPE 7) retinopathies with initial RETINAL CONE involvement. They are characterized by decreased VISUAL ACUITY; COLOR VISION DEFECTS; progressive loss of peripheral vision and night blindness.

Name: Medically Unexplained Symptoms
Description: Persistent health symptoms which remain unexplained after a complete medical evaluation. A cluster of symptoms that consistently appear together but without a known cause are referred to as a MEDICALLY UNEXPLAINED SYNDROME (MUS).

Name: Myocardial Contusions
Description: Bruise to the heart muscle due to blunt thoracic trauma.

Name: Myocardial Contusions
Description: Bruise to the heart muscle due to blunt thoracic trauma.

Name: Breast Carcinoma In Situ
Description: A condition in which abnormal cells have not spread outside the duct, lobule, or nipple to other tissues of the breast. There are 3 types of breast carcinoma in situ: DUCTAL CARCINOMA IN SITU; LOBULAR CARCINOMA IN SITU; and PAGET DISEASE OF THE NIPPLE.

Name: Breast Carcinoma In Situ
Description: A condition in which abnormal cells have not spread outside the duct, lobule, or nipple to other tissues of the breast. There are 3 types of breast carcinoma in situ: DUCTAL CARCINOMA IN SITU; LOBULAR CARCINOMA IN SITU; and PAGET DISEASE OF THE NIPPLE.

Name: Fracture Dislocation
Description: Fracture of a bone near an articulation with concomitant dislocation of that joint.

Name: Fracture Dislocation
Description: Fracture of a bone near an articulation with concomitant dislocation of that joint.

Description: Fracture of a bone near an articulation with concomitant dislocation of that joint.

Name: Salter-Harris Fractures
Description: Fractures involving a GROWTH PLATE.

Name: Salter-Harris Fractures
Description: Fractures involving a GROWTH PLATE.

Name: Salter-Harris Fractures
Description: Fractures involving a GROWTH PLATE.

Name: Lymphadenopathy
Description: Disease of LYMPH NODES which are abnormal in size, number or consistency.

Name: Breast Cancer Lymphedema
Description: Abnormal accumulation of lymph in the arm, shoulder and breast area associated with surgical treatment (e.g., MASTECTOMY) or radiation treatment of breast cancer.

Name: Breast Cancer Lymphedema
Description: Abnormal accumulation of lymph in the arm, shoulder and breast area associated with surgical treatment (e.g., MASTECTOMY) or radiation treatment of breast cancer.

Name: ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction
Description: A clinical syndrome defined by MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA symptoms; persistent elevation in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM; and release of BIOMARKERS of myocardial NECROSIS (e.g., elevated TROPONIN levels). ST segment elevation in the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also NON-ST ELEVATION MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION).

Name: ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction
Description: A clinical syndrome defined by MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA symptoms; persistent elevation in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM; and release of BIOMARKERS of myocardial NECROSIS (e.g., elevated TROPONIN levels). ST segment elevation in the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also NON-ST ELEVATION MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION).

Name: ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction
Description: A clinical syndrome defined by MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA symptoms; persistent elevation in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM; and release of BIOMARKERS of myocardial NECROSIS (e.g., elevated TROPONIN levels). ST segment elevation in the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also NON-ST ELEVATION MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION).

Name: ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction
Description: A clinical syndrome defined by MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA symptoms; persistent elevation in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM; and release of BIOMARKERS of myocardial NECROSIS (e.g., elevated TROPONIN levels). ST segment elevation in the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also NON-ST ELEVATION MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION).

Name: Non-ST Elevated Myocardial Infarction
Description: A myocardial infarction that does not produce elevations in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM. ST segment elevation of the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction).

Name: Non-ST Elevated Myocardial Infarction
Description: A myocardial infarction that does not produce elevations in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM. ST segment elevation of the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction).

Name: Non-ST Elevated Myocardial Infarction
Description: A myocardial infarction that does not produce elevations in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM. ST segment elevation of the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction).

Name: Non-ST Elevated Myocardial Infarction
Description: A myocardial infarction that does not produce elevations in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM. ST segment elevation of the ECG is often used in determining the treatment protocol (see also ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction).

Name: Hypophysitis
Description: Inflammation of the PITUITARY GLAND.

Name: Hypophysitis
Description: Inflammation of the PITUITARY GLAND.

Name: Teratozoospermia
Description: Conditions in which sperm show abnormal morphology.

Name: Teratozoospermia
Description: Conditions in which sperm show abnormal morphology.

Name: Teratozoospermia
Description: Conditions in which sperm show abnormal morphology.

Name: Ciliopathies
Description: Genetic disorders caused by defects in genes related to the primary CILIUM; BASAL BODY; or CENTROSOME. Primary features may include obesity, SKELETAL DYSPLASIA; POLYDACTYLY and malformations that primarily involve the liver, eye or kidneys.

Name: Ciliopathies
Description: Genetic disorders caused by defects in genes related to the primary CILIUM; BASAL BODY; or CENTROSOME. Primary features may include obesity, SKELETAL DYSPLASIA; POLYDACTYLY and malformations that primarily involve the liver, eye or kidneys.

Name: Margins of Excision
Description: The edges of tissue removed in a surgery for assessment of the effectiveness of a surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. When the margin is negative or not involved by tumor (e.g., CANCER) it suggests all of the tumor has been removed by the surgery.

Name: Spontaneous Perforation
Description: A pathological hole in an organ, blood vessel or other soft part of the body, occurring in the absence of external force.

Name: Ankyloglossia
Description: A severe congenital restriction of TONGUE movement, resulting from fusion or adherence of the tongue to the floor of the mouth. In partial ankyloglossia (tongue-tie) the LINGUAL FRENUM is abnormally short, or is attached too close to the tip of the tongue. OMIM: 106280

Name: Cancer Pain
Description: Pain that may be caused by or related to cellular, tissue, and systemic changes that occur during NEOPLASM growth, tissue invasion, and METASTASIS.

Name: Tertiary Lymphoid Structures
Description: Aggregates of immune cells formed near the sites of chronically inflamed, infected, or tumorous tissues.

Name: Propofol Infusion Syndrome
Description: Rare and often fatal drug complication which affects patients undergoing long-term treatment with high doses of PROPOFOL. It is characterized by METABOLIC ACIDOSIS; HYPERLIPIDEMIA; RHABDOMYOLYSIS; cardiovascular CIRCULATORY COLLAPSE; CARDIAC FAILURE; and KIDNEY FAILURE.

Name: Invasive Fungal Infections
Description: Mycoses which manifest as infections of deep tissue or blood.

Name: Surgical Wound
Description: An incision made during a surgical procedure.

Name: Chromothripsis
Description: Massive number of chromosomal rearrangements and shattering that occurs in cancer cells. The breakpoints are located within one chromosome or chromosome arm.

Name: Noncommunicable Diseases
Description: Diseases which are typically non-infectious in origin and do not transmit from an affected individual to others. The four main types of noncommunicable diseases are CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES (e.g., heart attacks and stroke), CANCER, chronic respiratory diseases (e.g., CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE and ASTHMA) and DIABETES MELLITUS.

Name: Epileptic Syndromes
Description: EPILEPTIC SEIZURES that are of similar type and age of onset and have other similar features (e.g., clinical course, EEG findings, genetic association and neuropathology).

Name: Occupational Stress
Description: Adverse psychological and behavioral reactions caused by the pressures and demands of employers or clients or other factors, such as the physical environment of the workplace, WORKPLACE VIOLENCE; or WORKPLACE BULLYING.

Name: Microvascular Rarefaction
Description: The reduction in density of the MICROVASCULATURE.

Name: Frailty
Description: A state of increased vulnerability to stressors, following declines in function and reserves across multiple physiologic systems, characterized by MUSCLE WEAKNESS; FATIGUE; slowed motor performance; low physical activity; and unintentional weight loss.

Name: Spotted Fever Group Rickettsiosis
Description: A group of arthropod-borne diseases caused by spotted fever bio-group members of RICKETTSIA. They are characterized by fever, headache, and petechial (spotted) rash.

Name: Spotted Fever Group Rickettsiosis
Description: A group of arthropod-borne diseases caused by spotted fever bio-group members of RICKETTSIA. They are characterized by fever, headache, and petechial (spotted) rash.

Name: Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury
Description: A rare but serious transfusion-related reaction in which fluid builds up in the lungs unrelated to excessively high infusion rate and/or volume (TRANSFUSION-ASSOCIATED CIRCULATORY OVERLOAD). Signs of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury include pulmonary secretions; hypotension; fever; DYSPNEA; TACHYPNEA; TACHYCARDIA; and CYANOSIS.

Name: Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury
Description: A rare but serious transfusion-related reaction in which fluid builds up in the lungs unrelated to excessively high infusion rate and/or volume (TRANSFUSION-ASSOCIATED CIRCULATORY OVERLOAD). Signs of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury include pulmonary secretions; hypotension; fever; DYSPNEA; TACHYPNEA; TACHYCARDIA; and CYANOSIS.

Name: Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury
Description: A rare but serious transfusion-related reaction in which fluid builds up in the lungs unrelated to excessively high infusion rate and/or volume (TRANSFUSION-ASSOCIATED CIRCULATORY OVERLOAD). Signs of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury include pulmonary secretions; hypotension; fever; DYSPNEA; TACHYPNEA; TACHYCARDIA; and CYANOSIS.

Name: Varicella Zoster Virus Infection
Description: Infection caused by HUMAN HERPES VIRUS 3 (e.g., CHICKENPOX and HERPES ZOSTER).

Name: Pain, Procedural
Description: Pain associated with examination, treatment or procedures.

Name: Trisomy 13 Syndrome
Description: A chromosome disorder associated with TRISOMY of all or part of CHROMOSOME 13. Clinical manifestations include CONGENITAL HEART DEFECTS (e.g., PATENT DUCTUS ARTERIOSUS), facial malformations (e.g., CLEFT LIP; CLEFT PALATE; COLOBOMA; MICROPHTHALMIA); HYPOTONIA, digit malformations (e.g., POLYDACTYLY or SYNDACTYLY), and SEIZURES and severe INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY associated with NERVOUS SYSTEM MALFORMATIONS.

Name: Trisomy 13 Syndrome
Description: A chromosome disorder associated with TRISOMY of all or part of CHROMOSOME 13. Clinical manifestations include CONGENITAL HEART DEFECTS (e.g., PATENT DUCTUS ARTERIOSUS), facial malformations (e.g., CLEFT LIP; CLEFT PALATE; COLOBOMA; MICROPHTHALMIA); HYPOTONIA, digit malformations (e.g., POLYDACTYLY or SYNDACTYLY), and SEIZURES and severe INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY associated with NERVOUS SYSTEM MALFORMATIONS.

Name: Trisomy 18 Syndrome
Description: A chromosome disorder associated with TRISOMY of all or part of CHROMOSOME 18. Clinical manifestations include INTRAUTERINE GROWTH RETARDATION; CLEFT PALATE; CONGENITAL HEART DEFECTS; MICROCEPHALY; MICROGNATHIA and clenched fists with overlapping fingers. Most affected fetuses do not survive to birth. Those who survive through their first year often have severe INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY.

Name: Vascular Ring
Description: Congenital vascular malformation in which the AORTA arch and its branches encircle the TRACHEA and ESOPHAGUS. Signs and symptoms include DYSPNEA; RESPIRATORY SOUNDS, especially with eating, DYSPHAGIA, persistent cough, and GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX or may be asymptomatic. Two most common types are double aortic arch and right aortic arch. It may be associated with other anomalies (e.g., DIGEORGE SYNDROME).

Name: Vascular Ring
Description: Congenital vascular malformation in which the AORTA arch and its branches encircle the TRACHEA and ESOPHAGUS. Signs and symptoms include DYSPNEA; RESPIRATORY SOUNDS, especially with eating, DYSPHAGIA, persistent cough, and GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX or may be asymptomatic. Two most common types are double aortic arch and right aortic arch. It may be associated with other anomalies (e.g., DIGEORGE SYNDROME).

Two most common types are double aortic arch and right aortic arch. It may be associated with other anomalies (e.g., DIGEORGE SYNDROME).

Name: Food Intolerance
Description: Digestive system disorder where a particular food irritates the digestive tract or cannot be properly digested (i.e., due to a lack of a digestive enzyme). It differs from FOOD HYPERSENSITIVITY which is an immune system disorder, usually due to specific proteins in food.  http://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/articles/problem-foods-is-it-an-allergy-or-intolerance.

Name: Tubular Sweat Gland Adenomas
Description: Various tubular forms of benign tumors of the SWEAT GLAND with glandular differentiation. Common types include syringocystadenoma papilliferum of the head and neck, and hidradenoma papilliferum of the vulva area. Hidradenoma papilliferum may be derived from mammary-like glands of the vulva.

Name: Tubular Sweat Gland Adenomas
Description: Various tubular forms of benign tumors of the SWEAT GLAND with glandular differentiation. Common types include syringocystadenoma papilliferum of the head and neck, and hidradenoma papilliferum of the vulva area. Hidradenoma papilliferum may be derived from mammary-like glands of the vulva.

Name: Interatrial Block
Description: Impaired or delayed impulse conduction between the right and left HEART ATRIA. Advanced interatrial blocks are often associated with arrhythmias (e.g., ATRIAL FLUTTER; and ATRIAL FIBRILLATION), direct conduction block via the Bachmann's bundle and concomitant left atrial enlargement. Syndrome of advanced interatrial block associated with SUPRAVENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA is referred to as Bayes syndrome.

Name: Interatrial Block
Description: Impaired or delayed impulse conduction between the right and left HEART ATRIA. Advanced interatrial blocks are often associated with arrhythmias (e.g., ATRIAL FLUTTER; and ATRIAL FIBRILLATION), direct conduction block via the Bachmann's bundle and concomitant left atrial enlargement. Syndrome of advanced interatrial block associated with SUPRAVENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA is referred to as Bayes syndrome.

Name: Interatrial Block
Description: Impaired or delayed impulse conduction between the right and left HEART ATRIA. Advanced interatrial blocks are often associated with arrhythmias (e.g., ATRIAL FLUTTER; and ATRIAL FIBRILLATION), direct conduction block via the Bachmann's bundle and concomitant left atrial enlargement. Syndrome of advanced interatrial block associated with SUPRAVENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA is referred to as Bayes syndrome.

Name: Cerebral Intraventricular Hemorrhage
Description: Bleeding within the CEREBRAL VENTRICLES. It is associated with intraventricular trauma, aneurysm, vascular malformations, hypertension and in VERY LOW BIRTH WEIGHT infants.

Name: Cerebral Intraventricular Hemorrhage
Description: Bleeding within the CEREBRAL VENTRICLES. It is associated with intraventricular trauma, aneurysm, vascular malformations, hypertension and in VERY LOW BIRTH WEIGHT infants.

Name: Cerebral Intraventricular Hemorrhage
Description: Bleeding within the CEREBRAL VENTRICLES. It is associated with intraventricular trauma, aneurysm, vascular malformations, hypertension and in VERY LOW BIRTH WEIGHT infants.

Name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Diseases
Description: Diseases that exhibit signs and symptoms suggestive of a connective tissue disease that do not fulfill clinical or diagnostic criteria for any one defined disease but overlap with criteria of multiple such diseases. Commonly overlapping diseases include systemic autoimmune connective tissue diseases such as RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS; SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS; and SYSTEMIC SCLEROSIS.

Name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Diseases
Description: Diseases that exhibit signs and symptoms suggestive of a connective tissue disease that do not fulfill clinical or diagnostic criteria for any one defined disease but overlap with criteria of multiple such diseases. Commonly overlapping diseases include systemic autoimmune connective tissue diseases such as RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS; SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS; and SYSTEMIC SCLEROSIS.

Name: Meconium Ileus
Description: Intestinal obstruction caused by congealed MECONIUM in the distal ILEUM and CECUM. It presents shortly after birth as a failure to pass meconium and frequently occurs in infants with CYSTIC FIBROSIS.

Name: Opium Dependence
Description: Strong physiological and emotional dependence on OPIUM.

Name: Oncogene Addiction
Description: The dependence of tumor cells on a single oncogenic pathway or protein for their continued proliferation and survival.

Name: Oncogene Addiction
Description: The dependence of tumor cells on a single oncogenic pathway or protein for their continued proliferation and survival.

Name: Median Arcuate Ligament Syndrome
Description: Compression of the CELIAC ARTERY by the median arcuate ligament, a fibrous band of the DIAPHRAGM, causing abdominal pain after eating and weight loss. OMIM: 116870

Name: Median Arcuate Ligament Syndrome
Description: Compression of the CELIAC ARTERY by the median arcuate ligament, a fibrous band of the DIAPHRAGM, causing abdominal pain after eating and weight loss. OMIM: 116870

Name: Median Arcuate Ligament Syndrome
Description: Compression of the CELIAC ARTERY by the median arcuate ligament, a fibrous band of the DIAPHRAGM, causing abdominal pain after eating and weight loss. OMIM: 116870

Name: Median Arcuate Ligament Syndrome
Description: Compression of the CELIAC ARTERY by the median arcuate ligament, a fibrous band of the DIAPHRAGM, causing abdominal pain after eating and weight loss. OMIM: 116870

Name: Nut and Peanut Hypersensitivity
Description: Allergic reaction to tree nuts and peanuts, including other LEGUMES, that is triggered by the immune system. It includes co-sensitization to other food (e.g., sesame seed).

Name: Kounis Syndrome
Description: A disorder of cardiac function secondary to hypersensitivity reactions. It is characterized by coexistence of acute coronary syndromes and cardiac MAST CELL and PLATELET ACTIVATION. It may be induced by exposure to drugs (e.g., antibiotics, anesthetics, contrast media), food, and environmental triggers (e.g., insect bites and stings, poison ivy).

Name: Kounis Syndrome
Description: A disorder of cardiac function secondary to hypersensitivity reactions. It is characterized by coexistence of acute coronary syndromes and cardiac MAST CELL and PLATELET ACTIVATION. It may be induced by exposure to drugs (e.g., antibiotics, anesthetics, contrast media), food, and environmental triggers (e.g., insect bites and stings, poison ivy).

It may be induced by exposure to drugs (e.g., antibiotics, anesthetics, contrast media), food, and environmental triggers (e.g., insect bites and stings, poison ivy).

Name: Substance Abuse, Oral
Description: Abuse, overuse, or misuse of a substance by ingestion.

Name: Smoldering Multiple Myeloma
Description: An asymptomatic and slow-growing PLASMA CELL dyscrasia characterized by presence of MYELOMA PROTEINS and clonal bone marrow plasma cells without end-organ damage (e.g., renal impairment). It is distinguished from MONOCLONAL GAMMOPATHY OF UNDETERMINED SIGNIFICANCE by a much higher risk of progression to symptomatic MULTIPLE MYELOMA.

Name: Smoldering Multiple Myeloma

It is distinguished from MONOCLONAL GAMMOPATHY OF UNDETERMINED SIGNIFICANCE by a much higher risk of progression to symptomatic MULTIPLE MYELOMA.

Name: Essential Hypertension
Description: Hypertension that occurs without known cause, or preexisting renal disease. Associated polymorphisms for a number of genes have been identified, including AGT, GNB3, and ECE1. OMIM: 145500

Name: Cardiac Conduction System Disease
Description: Diseases characterized by pathological irregularities in the HEART CONDUCTION SYSTEM. They may be associated with other heart diseases and syndromes (e.g., BRUGADA SYNDROME; NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASE, HEART BLOCKS), isolated or may result from injuries. You can have a conduction disorder without having an arrhythmia, but some arrhythmias arise from conduction disorders. OMIM: 601144.

Name: Hypoadrenocorticism, Familial
Description: Hereditary forms of Addison disease that may exhibit autosomal recessive or X-linked  inheritance. They are characterized by severe neurological symptoms, APNEA;  and death in infancy. OMIM: 240200

Name: Heavy Metal Poisoning
Description: Poisoning that results from chronic or acute ingestion, injection, inhalation, or skin absorption of HEAVY METALS. Acute and chronic exposures can cause ANEMIA; KIDNEY and LIVER damage; PULMONARY EDEMA; MEMORY LOSS and behavioral changes; bone deformities in children; and MISCARRIAGE or PREMATURE LABOR in pregnant women.

Name: Immunoglobulin Light-chain Amyloidosis
Description: A nonproliferative disorder of the PLASMA CELL characterized by excessive production and misfolding of IMMUNOGLOBULIN LIGHT CHAINS that form insoluble amyloid fibrils (see AMYLOID DEPOSITS) in various tissues. Clinical features include LIVER FAILURE; MULTIPLE MYELOMA; NEPHROTIC SYNDROME; RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY, and neuropathies.

Name: Immunoglobulin Light-chain Amyloidosis
Description: A nonproliferative disorder of the PLASMA CELL characterized by excessive production and misfolding of IMMUNOGLOBULIN LIGHT CHAINS that form insoluble amyloid fibrils (see AMYLOID DEPOSITS) in various tissues. Clinical features include LIVER FAILURE; MULTIPLE MYELOMA; NEPHROTIC SYNDROME; RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY, and neuropathies.

Name: Solitary Kidney
Description: Either a single or a single functioning kidney due to NEPHRECTOMY, birth defects or other kidney diseases.

Name: Solitary Kidney
Description: Either a single or a single functioning kidney due to NEPHRECTOMY, birth defects or other kidney diseases.

Name: Solitary Kidney
Description: Either a single or a single functioning kidney due to NEPHRECTOMY, birth defects or other kidney diseases.

Name: Solitary Kidney
Description: Either a single or a single functioning kidney due to NEPHRECTOMY, birth defects or other kidney diseases.

Name: Charles Bonnet Syndrome
Description: Repetitive visual hallucinations experienced mostly by elderly with diminished visual acuity or visual field loss, with awareness of the fictional nature of their hallucinations. It is not associated with delusions and other sensory hallucinations.

Name: Charles Bonnet Syndrome
Description: Repetitive visual hallucinations experienced mostly by elderly with diminished visual acuity or visual field loss, with awareness of the fictional nature of their hallucinations. It is not associated with delusions and other sensory hallucinations.

Name: Injection Site Reaction
Description: Adverse reactions that occur initially at the site of injection or infusion. Milder type is confined to a local allergic flare reaction. A more severe reaction is caused by extravasation of VESICANTS from the blood vessel at the site of injection and can cause damage to the surrounding tissue. In tumor flare reaction symptoms involve well beyond the injection site such as an increase in the tumor size and tumor markers levels, bone pain, and HYPERCALCEMIA.

Name: Clinical Deterioration
Description: A critical disease progression, often measured by a set of clinical parameters, which activates HOSPITAL RAPID RESPONSE TEAM.

Name: Alcoholic Korsakoff Syndrome
Description: A neurological disorder characterized by inattentiveness and the inability to form short term memories. It is caused by THIAMINE DEFICIENCY due to chronic ALCOHOLISM.

Name: Alcoholic Korsakoff Syndrome

Name: Travel-Related Illness
Description: Health problems associated with TRAVEL.

Name: Communicable Diseases, Imported
Description: Infectious diseases originating in one geographically delineated ecosystem that are carried (by travel or immigration) to another geographically delineated ecosystem by an infected individual, animal, or disease vector.

Name: Communicable Diseases, Imported
Description: Infectious diseases originating in one geographically delineated ecosystem that are carried (by travel or immigration) to another geographically delineated ecosystem by an infected individual, animal, or disease vector.

Name: Diverticular Diseases
Description: Diseases of the DIVERTICULUM often due to infection and/or inflammation (DIVERTICULITIS).

Name: Neonatal Brachial Plexus Palsy
Description: Perinatal nerve injury involving the BRACHIAL PLEXUS involving a weak or paralyzed upper extremity.

Name: Neonatal Brachial Plexus Palsy
Description: Perinatal nerve injury involving the BRACHIAL PLEXUS involving a weak or paralyzed upper extremity.

Name: Neonatal Brachial Plexus Palsy
Description: Perinatal nerve injury involving the BRACHIAL PLEXUS involving a weak or paralyzed upper extremity.

Name: Neurolymphomatosis
Description: Infiltration of the nervous system by malignant lymphoma cells.

Name: Adenocarcinoma of Lung
Description: A carcinoma originating in the lung and the most common lung cancer type in never-smokers. Malignant cells exhibit distinct features such as glandular epithelial, or tubular morphology. Mutations in KRAS, EGFR, BRAF, and ERBB2 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Adenocarcinoma of Lung
Description: A carcinoma originating in the lung and the most common lung cancer type in never-smokers. Malignant cells exhibit distinct features such as glandular epithelial, or tubular morphology. Mutations in KRAS, EGFR, BRAF, and ERBB2 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of Head and Neck
Description: The most common type of head and neck carcinoma that originates from cells on the surface of the NASAL CAVITY; MOUTH; PARANASAL SINUSES, SALIVARY GLANDS, and LARYNX. Mutations in TNFRSF10B, PTEN, and ING1 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of Head and Neck
Description: The most common type of head and neck carcinoma that originates from cells on the surface of the NASAL CAVITY; MOUTH; PARANASAL SINUSES, SALIVARY GLANDS, and LARYNX. Mutations in TNFRSF10B, PTEN, and ING1 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Chondrosarcoma, Clear Cell
Description: A chondrosarcoma of adolescence to old age of the proximal EPIPHYSES of long bones. It has variably clear cytoplasm of the mostly neoplastic CHONDROCYTES with little intervening matrix.

Name: Chondrosarcoma, Clear Cell
Description: A chondrosarcoma of adolescence to old age of the proximal EPIPHYSES of long bones. It has variably clear cytoplasm of the mostly neoplastic CHONDROCYTES with little intervening matrix.

Name: Carcinoma, Ovarian Epithelial
Description: A malignant neoplasm that originates in cells on the surface EPITHELIUM of the ovary and is the most common form of ovarian cancer. There are five histologic subtypes: papillary serous, endometrioid, mucinous, clear cell, and transitional cell. Mutations in BRCA1, OPCML, PRKN, PIK3CA, AKT1, CTNNB1, RRAS2, and CDH1 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Carcinoma, Ovarian Epithelial
Description: A malignant neoplasm that originates in cells on the surface EPITHELIUM of the ovary and is the most common form of ovarian cancer. There are five histologic subtypes: papillary serous, endometrioid, mucinous, clear cell, and transitional cell. Mutations in BRCA1, OPCML, PRKN, PIK3CA, AKT1, CTNNB1, RRAS2, and CDH1 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Sleepiness
Description: Compelling urge to sleep.

Name: Thyroid Cancer, Papillary
Description: An ADENOCARCINOMA that originates from follicular cells of the THYROID GLAND and accounts for the majority of THYROID CANCER cases. Cells exhibit enlarged, oval, or elongated morphologies with clear, round, nuclei. Fusions of RET, NTRK1, TPM3, and PCM1 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Thyroid Cancer, Papillary
Description: An ADENOCARCINOMA that originates from follicular cells of the THYROID GLAND and accounts for the majority of THYROID CANCER cases. Cells exhibit enlarged, oval, or elongated morphologies with clear, round, nuclei. Fusions of RET, NTRK1, TPM3, and PCM1 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
Description: A carcinoma that originates in the EPITHELIUM of the NASOPHARYNX and includes four subtypes: keratinizing squamous cell, non-keratinizing, basaloid squamous cell, and PAPILLARY ADENOCARCINOMA. It is most prevalent in Southeast Asian populations and is associated with EPSTEIN-BARR VIRUS INFECTIONS. Somatic mutations associated with this cancer have been identified in NPCR, BAP1, UBAP1, ERBB2, ERBB3, MLL2, PIK3CA, KRAS, NRAS, and ARID1A genes.

Name: Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
Description: A carcinoma that originates in the EPITHELIUM of the NASOPHARYNX and includes four subtypes: keratinizing squamous cell, non-keratinizing, basaloid squamous cell, and PAPILLARY ADENOCARCINOMA. Name: Craniofacial Fibrous Dysplasia
Description: Mostly benign fibro-osseous proliferation of the facial bones and skull. It can be either monostotic (localized to a single bone) or polyostotic (localized to more than one bone) type.

Name: Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: A carcinoma that originates usually from cells on the surface of the middle and lower third of the ESOPHAGUS. Tumor cells exhibit typical squamous morphology and form large polypoid lesions. Mutations in RNF6, LZTS1, TGFBR2, DEC1, and WWOX1 genes are associated with this cancer.

Name: Urinary Bladder, Underactive
Description: Symptom of underactive detrusor muscle of the URINARY BLADDER that contracts with abnormally reduced strength or duration resulting in an incomplete and/or prolonged bladder emptying.

Description: Symptom of underactive detrusor muscle of the URINARY BLADDER that contracts with abnormally reduced strength or duration resulting in an incomplete and/or prolonged bladder emptying.

Name: Healthcare-Associated Pneumonia
Description: Infection of the lung often accompanied by inflammation that is acquired through an interaction within a healthcare institution often through a therapeutic experience (e.g., use of catheters or ventilators).

Name: Post-Lyme Disease Syndrome
Description: A condition caused by long-lasting and ongoing infection with the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi resulting in progressive inflammatory neurologic, neuromuscular, and dermatologic manifestations including ENCEPHALITIS; MYELITIS; acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans; and ARTHRITIS.

Name: Post-Lyme Disease Syndrome
Description: A condition caused by long-lasting and ongoing infection with the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi resulting in progressive inflammatory neurologic, neuromuscular, and dermatologic manifestations including ENCEPHALITIS; MYELITIS; acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans; and ARTHRITIS.

Name: GATA2 Deficiency
Description: A rare disorder of the immune system with wide-ranging effects which include GATA2 Transcription Factor dysfunction, immunodeficiency, myelodysplastic syndrome (ineffective blood cell production), lung disease, and problems of the vascular and lymphatic system.

Name: GATA2 Deficiency
Description: A rare disorder of the immune system with wide-ranging effects which include GATA2 Transcription Factor dysfunction, immunodeficiency, myelodysplastic syndrome (ineffective blood cell production), lung disease, and problems of the vascular and lymphatic system.

Name: Cauda Equina Syndrome
Description: Compressive lesion affecting the nerve roots of the CAUDA EQUINA (e.g., compression, herniation, inflammation, rupture, or stenosis), which controls the function of the bladder and bowel. Symptoms may include neurological dysfunction of bladder or bowels, loss of sexual sensation and altered sensation or paralysis in the lower extremities.

Name: Cauda Equina Syndrome
Description: Compressive lesion affecting the nerve roots of the CAUDA EQUINA (e.g., compression, herniation, inflammation, rupture, or stenosis), which controls the function of the bladder and bowel. Symptoms may include neurological dysfunction of bladder or bowels, loss of sexual sensation and altered sensation or paralysis in the lower extremities.

Name: Immunoglobulin G4-Related Disease
Description: A spectrum of systemic autoimmune diseases in which IMMUNOGLOBULIN G4 plays a pathophysiologic role. It can affect multiple organs in highly variable presentations, characterized by inflammatory lesions composed of IgG4-positive PLASMA CELLS, further infiltrated by T helper cells (T-LYMPHOCYTES, HELPER-INDUCER) when linked to progressive FIBROSIS and eventual organ damage.

Name: Cone Dystrophy
Description: A general term which describes a group of rare eye disorders that affect the cone cells of the RETINA. Cone dystrophy can cause a variety of symptoms including decreased visual clarity or acuity when looking straight ahead (central vision), a reduced ability to see colors, and an increased sensitivity to light (PHOTOPHOBIA).

Name: Cone Dystrophy
Description: A general term which describes a group of rare eye disorders that affect the cone cells of the RETINA. Cone dystrophy can cause a variety of symptoms including decreased visual clarity or acuity when looking straight ahead (central vision), a reduced ability to see colors, and an increased sensitivity to light (PHOTOPHOBIA).

Name: Myopericytoma
Description: Rare myofibroma-like perivascular soft tissue tumor, usually benign, characterized by concentric perivascular proliferation.

Name: Myopericytoma
Description: Rare myofibroma-like perivascular soft tissue tumor, usually benign, characterized by concentric perivascular proliferation.

Name: Myopericytoma
Description: Rare myofibroma-like perivascular soft tissue tumor, usually benign, characterized by concentric perivascular proliferation.

Name: Pancreatic Intraductal Neoplasms
Description: EPITHELIAL NEOPLASMS with pancreatic ductal differentiation that arise from the EXOCRINE PANCREAS and grow mostly within the PANCREATIC DUCTS. They are characterized by the presence of intraductal masses with mostly papillary growth pattern. Overt production of MUCIN within the pancreatic duct is associated with pancreatic intraductal papillary-mucinous neoplasm but not intraductal tubulopapillary neoplasm.

Name: Pancreatic Intraductal Neoplasms
Description: EPITHELIAL NEOPLASMS with pancreatic ductal differentiation that arise from the EXOCRINE PANCREAS and grow mostly within the PANCREATIC DUCTS. They are characterized by the presence of intraductal masses with mostly papillary growth pattern. Overt production of MUCIN within the pancreatic duct is associated with pancreatic intraductal papillary-mucinous neoplasm but not intraductal tubulopapillary neoplasm.

Name: Pancreatic Intraductal Neoplasms
Description: EPITHELIAL NEOPLASMS with pancreatic ductal differentiation that arise from the EXOCRINE PANCREAS and grow mostly within the PANCREATIC DUCTS. They are characterized by the presence of intraductal masses with mostly papillary growth pattern. Overt production of MUCIN within the pancreatic duct is associated with pancreatic intraductal papillary-mucinous neoplasm but not intraductal tubulopapillary neoplasm.

Name: Body-Weight Trajectory
Description: A general pattern of body weight gain or loss over many years. Weight change trajectory is influenced by several determinants in children and adults.

Name: Gestational Weight Gain
Description: Increase in body weight of the mother during the course of her PREGNANCY.

Name: Obesity, Maternal
Description: BODY MASS INDEX in PREGNANT WOMEN that is excessively above the recommended cut-off.

Name: Obesity, Maternal
Description: BODY MASS INDEX in PREGNANT WOMEN that is excessively above the recommended cut-off.

Name: Obesity, Maternal
Description: BODY MASS INDEX in PREGNANT WOMEN that is excessively above the recommended cut-off.

Name: Vaccine-Preventable Diseases
Description: Diseases for which vaccines exist that can confer partial or complete protection. (World Health Organization vaccine-safety-training.org)

Name: Vector Borne Diseases
Description: Infectious diseases transmitted by DISEASE VECTORS.

Name: Narcotic-Related Disorders
Description: Disorders related to or resulting from abuse or misuse of NARCOTICS.

Name: Rumination Syndrome
Description: A gastrointestinal disorder characterized by repetitive and effortless regurgitation of ingested food from the stomach to the oral cavity in the early POSTPRANDIAL PERIOD. It is associated with functional gastrointestinal pathology (e.g., increased intra-gastric pressure) and psychiatric disorders (e.g., anxiety, depression). It is not limited to infants and distinct from GERD and VOMITING.

Name: Opioid-Induced Constipation
Description: CONSTIPATION associated with the use of OPIOIDS.

Name: Opioid-Induced Constipation
Description: CONSTIPATION associated with the use of OPIOIDS.

Name: Postoperative Cognitive Complications
Description: COGNITIVE IMPAIRMENT or functional decline after a surgical procedure.

Name: Extranodal Extension
Description: A penetration of LYMPH NODE metastatic cells through the nodal capsule into the perinodal fatty tissue used in a TUMOR STAGING system (the TNM staging system).

Name: Extranodal Extension
Description: A penetration of LYMPH NODE metastatic cells through the nodal capsule into the perinodal fatty tissue used in a TUMOR STAGING system (the TNM staging system).

Name: Anomalous Left Coronary Artery
Description: Malformations of left CORONARY ARTERY where it is connected to the PULMONARY ARTERY instead of the AORTA.

Name: Anomalous Left Coronary Artery
Description: Malformations of left CORONARY ARTERY where it is connected to the PULMONARY ARTERY instead of the AORTA.

Name: Anomalous Left Coronary Artery
Description: Malformations of left CORONARY ARTERY where it is connected to the PULMONARY ARTERY instead of the AORTA.

Name: Univentricular Heart
Description: Rare congenital heart malformation with a single ventricle (HEART VENTRICLES) instead of the usual two.

Name: Univentricular Heart
Description: Rare congenital heart malformation with a single ventricle (HEART VENTRICLES) instead of the usual two.

Name: Univentricular Heart
Description: Rare congenital heart malformation with a single ventricle (HEART VENTRICLES) instead of the usual two.

Name: Congenitally Corrected Transposition of the Great Arteries
Description: A rare heart defect that occurs when the HEART VENTRICLES and attached valves, the MITRAL VALVE and the TRICUSPID VALVE are reversed so that the AORTA and the PULMONARY ARTERY are connected to the wrong ventricle. Although the heart valves and the two great arteries, the PULMONARY ARTERY and the AORTA are transposed, the blood flows to the correct place because the ventricles are also reversed and therefore corrects the transposition. It often occurs with other structural heart abnormalities.

Name: Congenitally Corrected Transposition of the Great Arteries
Description: A rare heart defect that occurs when the HEART VENTRICLES and attached valves, the MITRAL VALVE and the TRICUSPID VALVE are reversed so that the AORTA and the PULMONARY ARTERY are connected to the wrong ventricle. Although the heart valves and the two great arteries, the PULMONARY ARTERY and the AORTA are transposed, the blood flows to the correct place because the ventricles are also reversed and therefore corrects the transposition. It often occurs with other structural heart abnormalities.

Name: Congenitally Corrected Transposition of the Great Arteries
Description: A rare heart defect that occurs when the HEART VENTRICLES and attached valves, the MITRAL VALVE and the TRICUSPID VALVE are reversed so that the AORTA and the PULMONARY ARTERY are connected to the wrong ventricle. Although the heart valves and the two great arteries, the PULMONARY ARTERY and the AORTA are transposed, the blood flows to the correct place because the ventricles are also reversed and therefore corrects the transposition. It often occurs with other structural heart abnormalities.

Name: Hamman-Rich Syndrome
Description: Acute idiopathic interstitial pneumonitis characterized by diffuse PULMONARY ALVEOLI damage with uniform edematous connective tissue proliferation. It is often associated with extensive fibroblastic distortion of the lung parenchyma and leads to ADULT RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME in later stages.

Name: Pancreaticobiliary Maljunction
Description: A group of anatomical variations in which the COMMON BILE DUCT and MAIN PANCREATIC DUCT are joined outside the duodenal wall often with abnormally long common channel rather than at the SPHINCTER OF ODDI.

Name: Pancreaticobiliary Maljunction
Description: A group of anatomical variations in which the COMMON BILE DUCT and MAIN PANCREATIC DUCT are joined outside the duodenal wall often with abnormally long common channel rather than at the SPHINCTER OF ODDI.

Name: Pancreaticobiliary Maljunction
Description: A group of anatomical variations in which the COMMON BILE DUCT and MAIN PANCREATIC DUCT are joined outside the duodenal wall often with abnormally long common channel rather than at the SPHINCTER OF ODDI.

Name: Chronic Urticaria
Description: Wheals (urticaria) and/or angioedema presented with daily symptoms lasting for more than 6 weeks. It may be classified into chronic spontaneous and chronic inducible urticaria depending on whether a specific trigger can be linked to the development of vascular reaction.

Name: Chronic Urticaria
Description: Wheals (urticaria) and/or angioedema presented with daily symptoms lasting for more than 6 weeks. It may be classified into chronic spontaneous and chronic inducible urticaria depending on whether a specific trigger can be linked to the development of vascular reaction.

Name: Chronic Urticaria
Description: Wheals (urticaria) and/or angioedema presented with daily symptoms lasting for more than 6 weeks. It may be classified into chronic spontaneous and chronic inducible urticaria depending on whether a specific trigger can be linked to the development of vascular reaction.

Name: Synesthesia
Description: The experience of involuntary sensory cross activation where the presentation of a particular stimulus elicits a secondary sensory-perceptual experience. It most commonly occurs in the association of color with linguistic stimuli such as letters, numbers, words, or music, but can also occur between other senses. Although synesthesia can be acquired or transient due to trauma or drug use, there is also a strong genetic component, with a prevalence of about 1 in 2,000 individuals and a female to male ratio of 6:1.

Name: Cyclodialysis Clefts
Description: Finding of a separation of the CILIARY BODY in the SCLERAL SPUR region, creating aqueous outflow from the ANTERIOR CHAMBER into suprachoroidal space between the CHOROID and the SCLERA. Persistent cyclodialysis clefts may be associated with OCULAR HYPOTENSION and OPTIC DISC EDEMA.

Name: Cyclodialysis Clefts
Description: Finding of a separation of the CILIARY BODY in the SCLERAL SPUR region, creating aqueous outflow from the ANTERIOR CHAMBER into suprachoroidal space between the CHOROID and the SCLERA. Persistent cyclodialysis clefts may be associated with OCULAR HYPOTENSION and OPTIC DISC EDEMA.

Name: Uveal Effusion Syndrome
Description: Rare disease characterized by suprachoroidal fluid accumulation between the CHOROID and the SCLERA, annular detachment of the CHOROID, often with secondary RETINAL DETACHMENT; OPTIC DISK EDEMA, and minimal signs of UVEITIS and INTRAOCULAR PRESSURE changes.

Name: Uveal Effusion Syndrome
Description: Rare disease characterized by suprachoroidal fluid accumulation between the CHOROID and the SCLERA, annular detachment of the CHOROID, often with secondary RETINAL DETACHMENT; OPTIC DISK EDEMA, and minimal signs of UVEITIS and INTRAOCULAR PRESSURE changes.

Name: Choroidal Effusions
Description: Finding of fluid accumulation between the CHOROID and the SCLERA.

Name: Choroidal Effusions
Description: Finding of fluid accumulation between the CHOROID and the SCLERA.

Name: Meibomian Gland Dysfunction
Description: A chronic dysfunction of MEIBOMIAN GLANDS characterized by altered tear film stability and function due to a decrease or alteration in lipid quality/content in meibum. It is often associated with evaporative-type DRY EYE SYNDROME.

Name: Optic Nerve Hypoplasia
Description: A group of rare genetic disorders characterized by underdeveloped OPTIC NERVES, resulting in increased incidences of vision impairment, CONGENITAL NYSTAGMUS and STRABISMUS. It may be syndromic, and is often associated with CNS malformations.

Name: Optic Nerve Hypoplasia
Description: A group of rare genetic disorders characterized by underdeveloped OPTIC NERVES, resulting in increased incidences of vision impairment, CONGENITAL NYSTAGMUS and STRABISMUS. It may be syndromic, and is often associated with CNS malformations.

Description: A group of rare genetic disorders characterized by underdeveloped OPTIC NERVES, resulting in increased incidences of vision impairment, CONGENITAL NYSTAGMUS and STRABISMUS. It may be syndromic, and is often associated with CNS malformations.

Description: A group of rare genetic disorders characterized by underdeveloped OPTIC NERVES, resulting in increased incidences of vision impairment, CONGENITAL NYSTAGMUS and STRABISMUS. It may be syndromic, and is often associated with CNS malformations.

Description: A group of rare genetic disorders characterized by underdeveloped OPTIC NERVES, resulting in increased incidences of vision impairment, CONGENITAL NYSTAGMUS and STRABISMUS. It may be syndromic, and is often associated with CNS malformations.

Name: Familial Exudative Vitreoretinopathies
Description: A group of inherited disorders characterized by incomplete development of the retinal vasculature. Its severity can vary from complete blindness in infancy, to mild or no visual problems, where small areas of vascular defects are observable only by FLUORESCEIN ANGIOGRAPHY. Exudative vitreoretinopathy 1 is associated with mutations in the FZD4 gene.

Name: Familial Exudative Vitreoretinopathies
Description: A group of inherited disorders characterized by incomplete development of the retinal vasculature. Its severity can vary from complete blindness in infancy, to mild or no visual problems, where small areas of vascular defects are observable only by FLUORESCEIN ANGIOGRAPHY. Exudative vitreoretinopathy 1 is associated with mutations in the FZD4 gene.

Name: Retinal Arterial Macroaneurysm
Description: An acquired dilation of the retinal artery often associated with systemic HYPERTENSION.

Name: Retinal Arterial Macroaneurysm
Description: An acquired dilation of the retinal artery often associated with systemic HYPERTENSION.

Name: Retinal Arterial Macroaneurysm
Description: An acquired dilation of the retinal artery often associated with systemic HYPERTENSION.

Name: Stargardt Disease
Description: A juvenile-onset macular dystrophy characterized by progressive loss of VISUAL ACUITY with normal acuity in peripheral VISUAL FIELDS. Other associated clinical features may include LIPOFUSCIN fundus autofluorescence, atrophy of the RETINAL PIGMENT EPITHELIUM, loss of color vision, PHOTOPHOBIA and PARACENTRAL SCOTOMA. Germline mutations in the ABCA4 gene have been identified in recessive and dominant diseases.

Name: Stargardt Disease
Description: A juvenile-onset macular dystrophy characterized by progressive loss of VISUAL ACUITY with normal acuity in peripheral VISUAL FIELDS. Other associated clinical features may include LIPOFUSCIN fundus autofluorescence, atrophy of the RETINAL PIGMENT EPITHELIUM, loss of color vision, PHOTOPHOBIA and PARACENTRAL SCOTOMA. Germline mutations in the ABCA4 gene have been identified in recessive and dominant diseases.

Name: Stargardt Disease
Description: A juvenile-onset macular dystrophy characterized by progressive loss of VISUAL ACUITY with normal acuity in peripheral VISUAL FIELDS.
